Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Probabilistic Methods for Addressing Complexity and Constraints in Protein Systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposed activity involves a research environment and educational curriculum dedicated to dealing efficiently with the complexity and constraints that protein molecules pose to computational studies. The emphasis is on elucidating the motions that proteins employ for biological function. This is a fundamental issue in the understanding of proteins and biology due to the central role of proteins in cellular processes.

The research addresses fundamental issues in protein modeling. Understanding proteins in silico involves searching a vast high-dimensional conformational space of inherently flexible systems with numerous inter-related degrees of freedom, complex geometry, physical constraints, and continuous motion. Three core research directions are identified. (1) Geometric constraints underlying protein motion are not trivial to identify or address. The proposed research exploits mechanistic analogies between proteins and robot kinematic linkages and investigates inverse kinematics techniques to efficiently formulate and address complex geometric constraints arising in diverse protein studies. (2) The funnel-like protein energy landscape exposes physics-based energetic constraints that are often demanding to address in silico. The proposed research pursues a multiscale treatment of energetic constraints in the context of probabilistic search, supporting coarse- and fine-grained levels of protein representational detail and converting between them with information gathered during exploration. (3) The conformational ensemble view of the protein state relevant for function necessitates search algorithms capable of exploring the high-dimensional conformational space and its rugged energy landscape. A novel probabilistic search framework is proposed that gathers information about the space it explores and employs this information to advance towards promising unexplored regions of the space. Taken together, these research directions allow addressing complexity in proteins by formulating and exploiting geometric and energetic constraints, thus narrowing the search space of interest to regions where the constraints are satisfied, and by employing a novel probabilistic framework with enhanced sampling capability able to feasibly search the relevant regions of the space.

The proposed activity promises to advance discovery and understanding both in the computer science and protein biophysics communities. Since most problems of practical interest are high-dimensional and often exhibit complex non-linear spaces, the proposed research cuts across and spans multiple areas in computer science, such as robot motion planning, optimization in complex non-linear spaces, and modeling and simulation of complex physics-based systems. In particular, the research will reveal effective probabilistic search strategies for continuous high-dimensional search spaces. Analogies with articulated mechanisms will offer insight on how to generate valid robot configurations in the presence of constraints. On the biophysical side, the research promises to advance protein modeling and understanding across diverse applications. The proposed activity involves interdisciplinary collaborations with computer scientists, biophysicists, and chemists. Findings and data will be disseminated broadly to enhance scientific understanding across diverse communities. Specific educational objectives focusing on curriculum design and outreach activities are formulated to employ the proposed research for broadening the participation of college and pre-college students, with a particular emphasis on underrepresented groups.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has created a synergistic research environment and educational curriculum addressing the complexity that proteins pose to studies aiming to advance our understanding of the role of these molecules in the inner working of a cell. Proteins are key players in processes that maintain and replicate a living cell. Advancing understanding of these molecules, and specifically how their form  governs their biological activities is a converging but challenging arena for disciplines spanning life and engineering sciences.

 

Questions on the form and function of biological matter were posed early Sir Turing. Decades of scientific enquiry have demonstrated just how fundamental form and changes to form are to function and function modulation. Indeed, experiment, theory, and computation show that proteins are not rigid but in perpetual motion, wiggling and jiggling their atoms, as Feynman famously put it in his Lectures on Physics. What we now know is that proteins harness their flexibility into productive events, switching between different three-dimensional forms/structures to interact with different molecular partners in the cell, thus using their structural dynamics to regulate molecular interactions and so modulate their biological function. Elucidating the role of structural dynamics in function is at the forefront of protein research.

 

This project has advanced algorithmic research on modeling protein flexibility by revealing the space of possible structures relevant for biological activity. This is a challenging undertaking, as proteins are complex systems with vast, high-dimensional structure spaces, numerous and inter-related degrees of freedom, complex geometry, physical constraints, and continuous motion. While computational research has traditionally focused on computing one or a few structures relevant for function, the algorithms and techniques that have resulted from this project have gone beyond static structures to computation of entire structural ensembles.

 

This project has linked together findings from computer science, statistical mechanics, and protein biophysics to effectively model protein flexibility relevant for function. The main contribution has been the design of probabilistic search algorithms that exploit the complexity and constraints of proteins to expedite the search for their biologically-relevant structures and the motions that connect them. Specifically, this project has identified geometric constraints characterizing protein flexibility and has leveraged them via mechanistic analogies between proteins and robotic kinematic linkages to expedite and focus the search for relevant structures. The work has also demonstrated how to effectively incorporate physics-based constraints at increasing levels of representational detail. Finally, the culmination of the work in this project has been the design of an adaptive, model-based, probabilistic search framework that employs information it gathers about the space it explores to adapt itself to relevant, unexplored regions, thus dynamically apportioning computational resources to regions of interest. Several algorithms have resulted from different realizations of this framework to address hallmark problems in protein modeling, such as de-novo protein structure prediction, protein-protein docking, and modeling of equilibrium protein structural dynamics.

 

Since most problems of practical interest are high-dimensional and often exhibit complex non-linear spaces, the work conducted in this project cuts across diverse areas, such as robot motion planning, optimization in complex non-linear spaces, and modeling and simulation of complex biological systems. As such, the work advances general knowledge and understanding in the broad area of computational modeling of complex systems in the presence of constraints. By focusing on challenging systems like proteins, this project has led to new methodologies and paradigms to model complex flexible systems characterized by numerous inter-related degrees of freedom and physical constraints. The project has impacted the computer science and protein biophysics communities and has fostered interdisciplinary collaborations between computational and biological scientists.

 

The research conducted in this project has been tightly integrated with educational activities that have broadened participation in computing, from the development of unique intra- and inter-departmental bioinformatics and bioengineering curricula, to outreach and mentoring of postdoctoral, graduate, undergraduate, and high-school students of diverse backgrounds. During the course of this project, four Ph.D. students, one postdoctoral student, four M.S. students, one community college student, twenty-one undergraduate students, and thirteen high-school students have been mentored and integrated in the research activities in this project. Several of these students have obtained recognition for their work in this project and have continued onto careers in academia and industry. Highlights include seven peer-reviewed research articles co-authored with undergraduate and high-school students, two of which first-authored by undergraduate students and one first-authored by a high-school student, one graduate student obtaining a tenure-track position in an academic institution, one graduate student obtaining a teaching position in an academic institution, five students obtaining positions in industry and federal laboratories, several undergraduate students obtaining recognition for their research in this project internally and externally, including a Finalist Male in the Computing Research Association Outstanding Undergraduate Research Award, more than thirty-percent of undergraduate students (fifty-percent of women undergraduates) continuing onto graduate studies, and one-hundred percent of high-school students continuing onto college.

 


Last Modified: 05/03/2018
Modified by: Amarda Shehu

Images (1 of )
  • Several variants of the H-Ras enzyme, healthy and diseased, have been studied in the Shehu laboratory. Structure spaces of select variants, computed with novel, stochastic optimization algorithms, allow formulating hypotheses for how mutations percolate to dysfunction via alteration of dynamics.
    Shehu Laboratory.
    Copyrighted
    Amarda Shehu
    Structure Spaces of H-Ras Variants
  • The structure space of the H-Ras enzyme has been revealed by a novel algorithm designed by the Shehu laboratory. All biological knowledge on known active structures of H-Ras has been synthesized, and the locations of such structures have been revealed on the computed space.
    Shehu Laboratory.
    Copyrighted
    Amarda Shehu
    Structure Space of H-Ras
  • The structure space of calmodulin (left panel) has been reveled by a robotics-inspired algorithm. The algorithm also queries the space to reveal motions connecting select biololgically-active structures, summarized on the right panel.
    Shehu Laboratory.
    Copyrighted
    Amarda Shehu
    Structure Space of Calmodulin
  • Jennifer Min Vanh, an undergraduate student mentored by the PI in research activities of this project, proudly presenting her research at the George Mason University Volgenau School of Engineering Undergraduate Research Celebration Event. Jennifer went on to win the Outstanding Project Award.
    Shehu Laboratory.
    Copyrighted
    Amarda Shehu
    Undergraduate student presenting research
